Patch Set 9:

Gunnar : Can this go in ?

Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)

> Patch Set 9:
> 
> Gunnar : Can this go in ?

I'm going to leave this one up to Ed / probably need some community discussion  
We asked Redfish here, https://redfishforum.com/thread/344/lamptest-functionality-system-schema and Redfish said no so technically we fulfilled https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/OEM_SCHEMAS.md but I still am not sure if this truly meets the bar for OEM. 

I feel most (Ed threw out 90%) of what this does can be accomplished by walking the inventory and setting the LEDs to true.

This has requirements "timeout (default is 4 minutes and can be configured), the lamptest is finished and all leds revert to their original state" that conflict with how Redfish does LED management. 

If another company came in later with a new OEM to get Inventory in one call (even if it does return some additional data), I would have a problem with that too. 

IMO we were too soft on allowing OEM when first writing bmcweb. This would be OEM we carry forever..? 

That said, you do have a design for this and asked Redfish.

Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)

> Patch Set 9:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> > Patch Set 9:
> > 
> > Gunnar : Can this go in ?
> 
> I'm going to leave this one up to Ed / probably need some community discussion  

Here's my primary worry with something like this going in: we haven't even implemented the Redfish base schema way to do it yet, so this feels like it's avoiding that work.  I understand that you have some unique requirements, and that's fine, but I'm quite worried about this thing conflicting with the LocationIndicatorActive properties once they go in, as your lamp test will need to interact with those properties significantly, as well as have representations for every LED that this targets.

My other concern is separation.  Redfish as a general rule does not have any of these "set all" style interfaces for a reason.  It's because when this gets orchestrated up into a higher rack manager, the schema itself still has to make sense and be useful to those higher layers when combined with hundreds of other systems.  If you have one resource, that sets properties on other resources, without any kind of link, that breaks the composability of redfish, as when setting "lamp test" on the resource, there's no way to know what things it effects.

As a third point (and this is definitely fixable), this doesn't really belong on systems;  The existing LED behaviors are in Chassis, that's where (if we figure out the other hurdles) something like this should go.

> We asked Redfish here, https://redfishforum.com/thread/344/lamptest-functionality-system-schema and Redfish said no so technically we fulfilled https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/OEM_SCHEMAS.md but I still am not sure if this truly meets the bar for OEM. 
> 
> I feel most (Ed threw out 90%) of what this does can be accomplished by walking the inventory and setting the LEDs to true.
> 
> This has requirements "timeout (default is 4 minutes and can be configured), the lamptest is finished and all leds revert to their original state" that conflict with how Redfish does LED management.

Isn't this what job service (possibly task service) Is for though?  Triggering an action on resources after a certain timer has expired?  It should be noted, all the lamp test examples I've seen in industry have no timeout, and are explicitly shut off through a followup command rather than a timeout.  I'm not here to tell you requirements, but removing the timeout would mean this could be 100% implemented in base redfish without OEM.

> 
> If another company came in later with a new OEM to get Inventory in one call (even if it does return some additional data), I would have a problem with that too.

+1

> 
> IMO we were too soft on allowing OEM when first writing bmcweb. This would be OEM we carry forever..?

The existing OEM schemas are causing no end of grief.  I still need to go clean up the OemManager mess, which has schemas that are straight up wrong, and have to break client behavior to make them correct.

> 
> That said, you do have a design for this and asked Redfish.

All this discussion is centred around redfish. How are we going to address the requirement of being able to initiate a lamp test via Operator Panel hardware button presses ?. Redfish is not the only initiator for lamp test.

This is a discussion about Redfish because this is a Redfish patchset?

I would assume that the operator panel would do a similar operation to Redfish, use the mapper to find all the LEDs, and issue SetProperty to turn them on.

Patch Set 9:

> Patch Set 9:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> > Patch Set 9:
> > 
> > (1 comment)

> > IMO we were too soft on allowing OEM when first writing bmcweb. This would be OEM we carry forever..?
> 
> The existing OEM schemas are causing no end of grief.  I still need to go clean up the OemManager mess, which has schemas that are straight up wrong, and have to break client behavior to make them correct.

I think you are saying "not causing any grief"? I disagree. 

The existing OEM schemas are excess code / schemas ( e.g. CrashDumps now with Dump support added to Redfish, could be modeled as non-OEM)
They have caused problems with updating schemas / running that script. https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/commit/2077899f6d4534d98ca2cca3bc9020dbc6a4aef9
All the reasons you list in https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/OEM_SCHEMAS.md apply to them. - Not standardized, lower quality of schema writing (there is errors in them), etc.

> 
> I think you are saying "not causing any grief"? I disagree. 

You interpreted this as the exact opposite of what I said.  "No end of grief" ie, "the grief is without end"  I think we're in complete agreement.  If I would wave a magic wand and have all the OEM schemas go away, I would.  I'm tempted to just delete/refactor all of them and just come up with the policy that OEM schemas have no API guarantees, but that's a different patchset, doc, and mailing list discussion that I'm not prepared for yet.

> 
> The existing OEM schemas are excess code / schemas ( e.g. CrashDumps now with Dump support added to Redfish, could be modeled as non-OEM)

Yep.  Completely agree.

> They have caused problems with updating schemas / running that script. https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/commit/2077899f6d4534d98ca2cca3bc9020dbc6a4aef9
> All the reasons you list in https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/OEM_SCHEMAS.md apply to them. - Not standardized, lower quality of schema writing (there is errors in them), etc.

We're in complete agreement.  I think you misread my comment.

At some point, we need to get together bugs for all the stuff that's broken with the OEM schemas and start getting it resolved over time.  It's going to take a while.

More details needed here.

What is a "lamp test".  What does it do?  How does it work?  How is it started, and how is it canceled?  Why were the existing LocationIndicator interfaces not suitable to this task?
Done, Some details have been added.
Generally redfish would model this as an Action, that returns a reference to task service.  "canceling" the action would involve issuing a state change to task service.
I think they followed the LocationIndicator interface and if you had an action you would need an additional property to know the status.

You'd use Task service to determine the status in what I proposed.

I guess, let me ask it this way;  Is "lamp test" a procedure that runs and eventually completes, or is it a "state" that the system can be in?

I guess I had imagined lamp test was something like "walk through each led and turn it on for a second" but I realized I assumed that.

I guess I assumed it was a "state" like lamp test on / lamp test off. haha. 
I pictured a toggle on the GUI.

I guess this goes back to my question above.  What is a "lamp test"?  Does it involve turning on all the LEDs on the board to verify they work?  If so, I would expect the existing indicator LED interfaces to be sufficient.

If it really is a state with on and off, why not just use the existing redfish APIs?
Yes,it is a state with on and off. The existing LocationIndicator interfaces is not suitable to this task, because we have to light all the leds, not just one identity led.
no need to mention "specific".  [Enable IBM Lamp Test functionality] is good enough
Done
Please encapsulate this in its own resource, then once that is done, please put this in its own IBM specific file, so we can track maintenance of it properly.
Done, I moved it to oem/ibm/lamp_test.hpp

Hi Vishwanatha，As I have explained to you on Discord, the lampTest here is not a necessary parameter in dopatch.

as above
You seem to be missing schema definitions for the properties within this oem resource.

> Yes, I don't know how to write this schema, I have tried many ways to write it but failed.

This is generally why writing OEM schemas isn't recommended, and it's significantly easier to use existing resources, or have spec additions added when you need help, as they get a much better review..  Schemas are not easy to write properly.  Feel free to reach out to the redfish DMTF committee for help, although if you catch me on discord, I can help you with the knowledge I do have.  Gunnar is also a good resource for this kind of thing.

> Could you give me some help? thank you very much. What I want to achieve is:
> 
>    "Oem": {
>      "@odata.type": "#OemComputerSystem.Oem",
>      "IBM": {
>        "@odata.type": "#OemComputerSystem.IBM",
>        "LampTest": false
>      }

Understood.  Your best bet would be to start reading through the redfish/odata documentation on how all these things work.

This file is generic to all openBMC systems, it cannot contain IBM-specific features.

also, generally the Oem would be omitted from the "IBMOem" name.
Sorry,but which file should I put it in?
You'll need to sort that out and propose something.  I suspect the file you need doesn't exist yet.

This doesn't track for me.  There isn't a single LocationIndicator instance, as this statement seems to imply, there is one per component.   They provide direct access to the LEDs, and a simple looping over all indicator properties on all resources, and turning them all on from the client seems like a much better fit for the redfish API way of doing things, as it would also allow the client to verify that all components where the LEDs are expected exist.  The only thing that's missing then is the timeout, but that seems relatively easy to implement with Job service, as a stand alone item that would be started before the routine was done.  Unless I'm mistaken, that seems to fit well within the non-OEM redfish schemas.

Can you add more details about why the existing redfish APIs wont' work as I've described?

Lamp_Test is a IBM only requirement at this moment. The expectation is that the client calls "Do The Lamp test" and the BMC implementation will do what it means. Currently, what it means is that we :
- Light up all the Indicator LEDs that are on the enclosure
- Also, light-up some of the Green Power LEDs that have the software control
- Send a command over to the LCD display daemon to exercise LCD
- Send a PLDM command over to the Host so that Host can light-up the LEDs for all the external attached drawers.

- Wait for configured time
- Revert to old states

We can not offload this onto redfish clients and do LocationIndicatorActive one by one since we would then spread the logic into different redfish clients. Also, we can not achieve the above 4 functionalities if we offloaded that onto clients. This becomes challenging when we have more than 1 redfish clients.

> Lamp_Test is a IBM only requirement at this moment. The expectation is that the client calls "Do The Lamp test" and the BMC implementation will do what it means. Currently, what it means is that we :
> - Light up all the Indicator LEDs that are on the enclosure
> - Also, light-up some of the Green Power LEDs that have the software control
> - Send a command over to the LCD display daemon to exercise LCD
> - Send a PLDM command over to the Host so that Host can light-up the LEDs for all the external attached drawers.
> 
> - Wait for configured time
> - Revert to old states
> 
> We can not offload this onto redfish clients and do LocationIndicatorActive one by one since we would then spread the logic into different redfish clients.

I'm not following this comment.  Well behaved Redfish clients already need to know how to walk the tree, and the logic is minimal (if component has an LED, set to ON).  Having all your LEDs enumerated in Redfish would give you 90% of the above.  I could see having an OEM resource for the LCD test, as that's pretty specific, but otherwise, I feel like there are resources to do what you're trying to do, it just requires that all the LEDs be enumerated in the tree, which is a good thing to have anyway.

> Also, we can not achieve the above 4 functionalities if we offloaded that onto clients.

You can achieve 90% of the above, then have an OEM command for the last little part that's actually an OEM behavior.

The only other strange part is the timeout, but that seems easily modeled using task service.

> This becomes challenging when we have more than 1 redfish clients.

Having an OEM resource seems more challenging, as now all redfish clients need to implement the OEM IBM only parameter, as well as detect whether or not the system is an IBM system, and fall back to the redfish defined behavior.

Thanks for the comments Ed. However, it's a feature that we want to contain in the server code for the reasons mentioned above. Also, there are some one-off behaviors that we need to enforce on led-manager when the lamp test is happening. So, we can not rely on clients to do right thing for us. We have gone over these in the phosphor-dbus-interfaces commit that I ended up abandoning.
Also, as mentioned above , Redfish is not the only initiator of this feature. We have Operator Panel hardware in IBM systems and users can initiate the lamp test by pressing some key combinations.

> Thanks for the comments Ed. However, it's a feature that we want to contain in the server code for the reasons mentioned above. 

I've listed alternatives that don't require OEM properties, and implement what you want above.  Yes, it requires clients to be more complex, but given the cost burden of maintaining oem properties, it seems well worth it.

Also, considering the variety of LEDs you want to change that we don't even have them modeled in Redfish yet, I'd recommend that we need to model those first, before trying to add them to an OEM property.

> Also, there are some one-off behaviors that we need to enforce on led-manager when the lamp test is happening. So, we can not rely on clients to do right thing for us.

Can you give some examples of what these one-off behaviors are that you'd like to enforce?

> We have gone over these in the phosphor-dbus-interfaces commit that I ended up abandoning.

I will add it to my reading list, to see if I can understand your use cases better.
This seems like an odd use of the led groups API.  "lamp test" isn't really a group.  Maybe it should be "all" or something similar?
